questions.question_text:
Universal Containers implemented Sales Cloud and requested that only certain branch staff trained to sell high-risk products can create opportunities for high-risk products.

How should an architect allow only specific branch staff to sell high-risk products?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
share rule isn't available for price book

choices.A: Set the price book organization-wide default (OWD) to View Only and share the price book (High Risk) with the trained staff.
choices.C: Set the price book OWD to View Only and share the (High Risk) price book with the trained staff via manual sharing.
choices.B: Set the price book OWD to View Only and share the (High Risk) price book with the trained staff via a sharing rule.

questions.question_text:
Universal Containers has implemented Customer Community with Customer Community Plus licenses for its distributors. Retail distributors have part-time agents who work for multiple distributors. Those agents should have access to other distributor accounts as well.

What should be configured to grant agents access to different distributor accounts?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Improvement on my first response:
Sharing sets are specifically designed for community users.
Account Contact Relationships (ACR) allow you to define relationships between contacts and multiple accounts
This maintains proper data security while allowing flexible access

B. is not it, because sharing rules are primarily for internal users and they can't leverage the Account Contact Relationship model. 

C. is not it, because it's an unnecessarily complex solution that uses custom code when there are declarative tools that can do the same thing.

Selected Answer: A
This is a best answer question, so A is the choice.

A, B, C provide the needed functionality. Sharing Sets are specifically for Customer and Partner communities (external users) and use profiles instead of of roles and public groups.

Sharing rules can be used for role based licenses only (Customer Community Plus, Partner User), so this is a viable option. Sharing rules are generally used for broader sharing criteria and may not be as suitable for this specific scenario and maintenance issues will arise.

choices.C: Use Apex sharing to share distributor accounts with agents using the Account_Share table.
choices.A: Create a sharing set to share distributor accounts with agents using account contact relationship.
choices.B: Create sharing rules to share distributor accounts with agents.

choices.A: Enforcement of a user's record sharing
choices.C: Enforcement of a user's Field-Level Security

questions.question_text: Which functionality does the system method “runAs()” verify when writing test methods?

discussion.content:
A. Enforcement of a user's record sharing
B is wrong answer

Selected Answer: A
Answer should be A.
As per: https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.apexcode.meta/apexcode/apex_testing_tools_runas.htm

Selected Answer: B
A: you don't need to enforce the record visibility when running Apex classes in system context, because there aren't any restricitons
B: is correct
C: isShareable doesn't exist

Selected Answer: A
A. is the most directly relevant to the issue of enforcing record visibility in Apex classes running in system mode, which is a critical concern for maintaining data security and compliance.

B. is good, but it doesn't directly fix record visibility issues.

C. isShareable is not valid in Apex, so is totally wrong.

choices.B: Create test classes including runAs to test different users accessing the data.
choices.C: Use isShareable, isEditable, and isCreatable to enforce field permissions.
choices.A: Once that Apex runs on system mode, the development team needs to enforce record visibility.

choices.A: The Sales Users profile does not have access to the remaining fields.

questions.question_text:
Universal Containers (UC) has created a custom Invoice object. Standard sales users at UC can see the records in search layout, but when they click to view the detail, only record name, created date, and last modified date are shown. When the system admin accesses it, he or she sees the full record detail with many more data fields.

What is the likely cause of this issue?

discussion.content: I think A is correct because sharing rules don't give access to fields but only to records

Selected Answer: A
Must be A: it's about field permissions and not record access.
A. The Sales Users profile does not have access to the remaining fields.
